channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Brazil to Focus on Past Abuses
item.description: Brazil’s defense minister has agreed to investigate military facilities where human rights abuses were believed to have been committed during the country’s 21-year dictatorship.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Eight Soldiers Are Killed as Election Campaign Begins
item.description: A suicide bomber rammed his explosive-laden car into a convoy of army vehicles in the city, and hours later, gunmen sprayed an army checkpoint with bullets.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Police Break Up Protest Over Voting Irregularities
item.description: Television reports showed two antiriot vehicles moving along a street and firing water cannons at groups calling for a recount.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Islamic Leader Is Killed
item.description: A radical Islamic leader who had been accused by the United States and the United Nations of supporting the Shabab, a Somali militant group, was assassinated late Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Syria: War Deaths Top 150,000, Human Rights Group Says
item.description: The death toll in Syria’s three-year-old conflict has exceeded 150,000, an activist group said Tuesday as fighting raged across the country.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Small Area Open Near Fukushima
item.description: Japan reopened a small part of the 12-mile evacuation zone around the destroyed Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant, allowing residents to return to live in their homes for the first time since the accident three years ago.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Earthquake Hits Off Coast of North Chile
item.description: An 8.2-magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of northern Chile on Tuesday night, forcing an evacuation along the country’s long coastline and putting the entire Pacific Coast of South America on tsunami alerts.
item.dc:creator: By PASCALE BONNEFOY and SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: People gather at a stadium in Iquique after a tsunami alert was issued following a 8.0-magnitude earthquake off Chile's northern coast on Tuesday.

item.title: House Approves Funds for Ukraine
item.description: President Obama said he would sign the bill providing for loan guarantees and sanctions against Russia.
item.dc:creator: By JADA F. SMITH

item.title: Afghan Women See Hope in the Ballot Box
item.description: In coming elections, female candidates are trying to advance women’s rights before the possibility of Western influence fading and leaders reconciling with the Taliban.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghan women cheered for Habiba Sarobi, a candidate for vice president in Saturday’s election, as she spoke in Kabul on Monday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: 11 Detained After Protesting ‘Black Jail’ in China
item.description: Eleven people, including four well-known lawyers representing families of Falun Gong adherents and other people held in one of China’s notorious “black jails,” have been detained in the northern province of Heilongjiang, the police say.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: To Protect Foreigners, Afghanistan Shuts Down Their Hangouts
item.description: After a wave of violence in the Afghanistan capital, several restaurants and guesthouses popular with foreigners were ordered closed until after elections on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Table Talk in Kabul is one of several restaurants told to close until after an election on Saturday.

item.title: Abbas Takes Defiant Step, and Mideast Talks Falter
item.description: An effort by President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority to join 15 international agencies threatened to derail the fraught peace talks.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN, MICHAEL R. GORDON and MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Mahmoud Abbas met with Palestinian leaders on Tuesday, signing documents to join 15 international bodies.

item.title: Authorities Kill Gang Leader, Mexico Says
item.description: Mexican authorities said they had killed another leader of the Knights Templar drug gang, adding to a string of successes against the organization that seemed to leave only one boss still at large.
item.dc:creator: By PAULINA VILLEGAS

item.title: House Approves Funds for Ukraine
item.description: Loan guarantees and sanctions against Russia are meant to support the new government in Kiev.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A self-defense recruit during a combat class in Kiev's Independence Square in March.

item.title: Ebola Reaches Guinean Capital, Stirring Fears
item.description: With 13 Ebola cases in Conakry, Guinea’s densely populated capital, residents are on edge, with some carrying bottles of bleach and pharmacies selling out of hand sanitizer.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Relief workers from Doctors Without Borders carried a body on Tuesday at a center for Ebola victims in Guéckédou, a town in Guinea at the heart of an epidemic that has killed more than 80 people.

item.title: Rome Journal: Aging Church Passes Digital Collection Plate
item.description: St. Francis at Ripa church in Rome has turned to the crowdfunding website Kickstarter to raise money for a renovation.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rev. Stefano Tamburo in the room at St. Francis at Ripa church where St. Francis of Assisi slept during visits to Rome.

item.title: Health Worsens for Father of American Imprisoned in Tehran
item.description: The family of Amir Hekmati, the former Marine imprisoned in Iran, released a letter from his ailing father’s doctor asking Iran to free Mr. Hekmati.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Caring for the Dead: It’s the Thought That Counts
item.description: Chinese who cannot afford the time or expense to travel to attend to their relatives’ graves for the “tomb sweeping” festival can employ others to do it. For a fee, they’ll even cry on your behalf.
item.dc:creator: By MIA LI
item.media:description: Visitors crowded a cemetery last year in Jinjiang, in eastern China, for Qingming, the "tomb sweeping" festival.

item.title: Leader of China Aims at Military With Graft Case
item.description: China charged Lt. Gen. Gu Junshan with financial crimes and abuse of power in a case seen as part of an effort to tighten the party’s control over the military.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN ANSFIELD
item.media:description: A People’s Liberation Army guard at the Bayi Building in Beijing. President Xi Jinping has reportedly called military corruption the “Gu Junshan phenomenon.”

item.title: Russia Tightens Pressure on Ukraine With Rise in Natural Gas Price
item.description: Gazprom, the Russian energy company, increased the price by 44 percent even as American and Russian diplomats groped toward a settlement over Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: With Plane Still Missing, Legal Moves for Payouts Start
item.description: Although there is still no certainty that Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 has crashed, lawyers are pursuing families that might be granted multimillion-dollar settlements.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG and KIRK SEMPLE
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Monica R. Kelly is pursuing families of passengerson the missing Malaysia Airlines jet that might be granted multimillion-dollar settlements.

item.title: NATO to Firm Up Its Presence in Eastern Europe as It Halts Cooperation With Russia
item.description: The move by NATO codifies and expands on steps the alliance had already taken to protest Russia’s intervention in Crimea.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 1
item.description: A man taking a bow before a bronze bull outside the Bombay Stock Exchange in Mumbai, Maharashtra.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A man bowing in obeisance as he walks past the bronze bull outside the Bombay Stock Exchange in Mumbai, Maharashtra. India's central bank kept key interest rates steady in a widely anticipated move less than a week before the start of parliamentary elections.

item.title: At War Blog: A Reporter Clutches Life After a Loss That Hits Home
item.description: Habib Zahori on losing his friend Sardar Ahmed, a journalist who was killed along with his wife and two of their three children in a Taliban attack on a hotel in Kabul.
item.dc:creator: By HABIB ZAHORI
item.media:description: People prayed for Sardar Ahmad, a prominent Afghan journalist, who was killed along with his wife and their two young children at the Serena Hotel in Kabul, on March 21.

item.title: Unemployment Malaise Lingers in Euro Zone
item.description: While the jobless rate ticked higher in France and set a record in Italy, it stood at 11.9 percent in the wider 18-nation currency bloc, unchanged from January’s revised figure.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY
item.media:description: Job seekers outside an unemployment office in Madrid last month. Spain's unemployment rate stood at 25.6 percent in February.
